verses.text: When the Canaanite king of Arad, who lived in the Negev, heard that Israel was coming by the way of Atharim, he fought against Israel and took some of them captive.
verses.comment: The words follow Hebrew order, 'heard...by the way of Atharim'; 'took some of them captive' reflects literal phrasing.

verses.text: Israel made a vow to the LORD and said, 'If You will indeed hand over these people into my hand, I will completely destroy their cities.'
verses.comment: 'Hand over…into my hand' is a literal rendering.

verses.text: The LORD listened to the voice of Israel and gave up the Canaanites. They completely destroyed them and their cities. So the place was called Hormah.
verses.comment: 'Completely destroyed' translates 'herem', meaning devoted to destruction.

verses.text: They set out from Mount Hor by the way to the Red Sea, to go around the land of Edom. But the soul of the people became impatient on the way.
verses.comment: 'The soul of the people' is a literal phrase.

verses.text: And the people spoke against God and against Moses, 'Why have you brought us up out of Egypt to die in the wilderness? For there is no bread, and there is no water, and we loathe this worthless food.'
verses.comment: 'Worthless food' = 'light bread' (manna), expressing their disdain.

verses.text: Then the LORD sent fiery serpents among the people, and they bit the people, so that many of the people of Israel died.
verses.comment: 'Fiery serpents' literally, burning snakes, probably describing venomous bites.

verses.text: So the people came to Moses and said, 'We have sinned, for we have spoken against the LORD and against you. Pray to the LORD, that He take away the serpents from us.' So Moses prayed for the people.
verses.comment: Literal rendering; depicts repentance.

verses.text: The LORD said to Moses, 'Make a fiery serpent and set it on a pole. And everyone who is bitten, when he looks at it, shall live.'
verses.comment: 'Pole' is literal. Refers forward to John 3:14.

verses.text: So Moses made a bronze serpent and put it on a pole. If a serpent bit anyone, he would look at the bronze serpent and live.
verses.comment: Literal translation; 'bronze' is a literal rendering for Hebrew 'nechosheth'.

verses.text: The people of Israel set out and camped at Oboth.
verses.comment: Simple literal phrasing.

verses.text: They set out from Oboth and camped at Iye-abarim, in the wilderness that is opposite Moab, toward the sunrise.
verses.comment: 'Toward the sunrise' literally, 'toward the east'.

verses.text: From there they set out and camped in the Valley of Zered.
verses.comment: Simple literal rendering.

verses.text: From there they set out and camped on the other side of the Arnon, which is in the wilderness that comes out of the territory of the Amorites. For the Arnon is the border of Moab, between Moab and the Amorites.
verses.comment: 'On the other side of the Arnon' is literal.

verses.text: Therefore it is said in the Book of the Wars of the LORD: 'Waheb in Suphah, and the valleys of the Arnon,
verses.comment: Translation preserves the uncertainty of 'Waheb in Suphah'.

verses.text: and the slope of the valleys that extends to the dwelling of Ar, and leans to the border of Moab.'
verses.comment: 'Slope of the valleys' is literal phraseology.

verses.text: From there they went to Beer; that is the well where the LORD said to Moses, 'Gather the people together, and I will give them water.'
verses.comment: 'Beer' means 'well'; translation is literal.

verses.text: Then Israel sang this song: 'Spring up, O well! Sing to it!
verses.comment: Literal lines; an early Hebrew poetic form.

verses.text: the well that the leaders sank, that the nobles of the people dug with the scepter and with their staffs.' And from the wilderness they went to Mattanah,
verses.comment: Phrasing kept literal and poetic.

verses.text: and from Mattanah to Nahaliel, and from Nahaliel to Bamoth,
verses.comment: Station names transliterated.

verses.text: and from Bamoth to the valley that is in the country of Moab, to the top of Pisgah, which looks down on the wasteland.
verses.comment: 'Looks down' is literal.

verses.text: Then Israel sent messengers to Sihon king of the Amorites, saying,
verses.comment: Lit. 'sent messengers...saying...'

verses.text: 'Let us pass through your land. We will not turn aside into field or vineyard; we will not drink water from wells. We will go by the King's Highway until we have passed through your territory.'
verses.comment: Direct quotation. 'King's Highway' is transliterated.

verses.text: But Sihon would not allow Israel to pass through his territory. Instead, Sihon gathered all his people and went out against Israel in the wilderness, and came to Jahaz and fought against Israel.
verses.comment: 'Would not allow' is a literal rendering.

verses.text: Israel struck him with the edge of the sword and took possession of his land from the Arnon to the Jabbok, as far as the Ammonites, for the border of the Ammonites was strong.
verses.comment: 'With the edge of the sword' is a literal Hebrew phrase.

verses.text: Israel took all these cities, and Israel lived in all the cities of the Amorites, in Heshbon and in all its villages.
verses.comment: 'Villages' literally means 'daughters', i.e., dependent towns.

verses.text: For Heshbon was the city of Sihon king of the Amorites, who had fought against the former king of Moab and taken all his land out of his hand, as far as the Arnon.
verses.comment: 'Taken...out of his hand' is a literal expression.

verses.text: Therefore those who speak in proverbs say, 'Come to Heshbon, let it be built; let the city of Sihon be established.
verses.comment: Literal rendering of proverb.

verses.text: 'For fire went out from Heshbon, flame from the city of Sihon. It devoured Ar of Moab, the lords of the heights of Arnon.'
verses.comment: 'Lords' is literal for Hebrew 'ba'ale'.

verses.text: 'Woe to you, O Moab! You are undone, O people of Chemosh! He has given his sons as fugitives, and his daughters into captivity, to Sihon king of the Amorites.'
verses.comment: Retains the literal roles of Chemosh.

verses.text: 'But we have shot at them; Heshbon is perished as far as Dibon; and we laid waste as far as Nophah, which goes to Medeba.'
verses.comment: 'Shot at them' is literal; possible reference to archery.

verses.text: So Israel lived in the land of the Amorites.
verses.comment: Direct statement from Hebrew.

verses.text: Moses sent to spy out Jazer, and they captured its villages and drove out the Amorites who were there.
verses.comment: 'Captured its villages' is literal.

verses.text: Then they turned and went up by the way of Bashan. And Og king of Bashan came out against them, he and all his people, to battle at Edrei.
verses.comment: 'By the way of Bashan' is literal.

verses.text: But the LORD said to Moses, 'Do not fear him, for I have given him into your hand, and all his people, and his land. Do to him as you did to Sihon king of the Amorites, who lived at Heshbon.'
verses.comment: Direct speech, literal rendering.

verses.text: So they struck him, and his sons, and all his people, until there was no survivor left. And they possessed his land.
verses.comment: 'No survivor left' is literal, emphasizing total defeat.
